definition: to let go of sth held in one's mouth/(fig.) to relent/to yield
loose/to loosen/to relax/floss (dry, fluffy food product made from shredded, seasoned meat or fish, used as a topping or filling)
mouth/classifier for things with mouths (people, domestic animals, cannons, wells etc)/classifier for bites or mouthfuls

sentences.english: See LiuMin seems to some let go, victory however because be has no head for wine drunk.
sentences.chinese: 眼看劉敏似乎有些鬆口，勝利卻因不勝酒力醉倒了。

sentences.english: After getting out of the valley, all greatly relaxed, looking back and taking pictures.
sentences.chinese: 出到谷口大家紛紛鬆口氣，回望，拍照。

sentences.english: The boss gave her a break and let her try again.
sentences.chinese: 老闆讓她鬆口氣，讓她再試一次。

sentences.english: You can breathe a sigh of relief.Your drug test came back negative.
sentences.chinese: 鬆口氣吧，你的藥檢呈陰性。

sentences.english: After $200 he tells them the room number.
sentences.chinese: 得了200美金後，他便鬆口告知房間號。

sentences.english: The stevedores tossedthrew the bags from high place into the hold. That brought on a lot of bags with seams slack.
sentences.chinese: 裝卸工從高處向艙裏拋袋子，這使得大量袋子鬆口。

sentences.english: On this issue have any signs of relenting.
sentences.chinese: 對這個問題有任何鬆口的跡象。

definition: two simultaneous happy events in the family
to question intensely/to interrogate/to demand information
(coll.) (of a couple) to display affection in public or by posting photos on social media
widely spread/widely rumored/stories abound/(sb's exploits are) widely circulated
not to mention (idiom); to say not one word/fig. to omit mention (of a non-person or embarrassing topic)/to censor
(of an expectant mother) to be in labor
to see with one's own eyes/to witness
